content.body: sees that HTML 3.2 said <input type=image> should always send x and y coordinates, then HTML 4 instead said 'ismap' was required for that (though the DTD didn't allow it on <input> until HTML 4.01)
hey.  just curious: are there any recent summaries of HTML5 progress (either through W3C or WHATWG)?
jacobolus: http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker ?
How recent, and how summarised?
Philip`: sometime in the last few months.  paragraphs not commit logs. :)
Philip`: big ideas, not minor fixes, etc.
don't think so
okay, no worries. :)
Hmm, I can't even remember any big changes recently
which is probably caused by my memory rather than by a lack of big changes
http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/help-whatwg.org/2007-August/000070.html
has recently been revamped
also, is there any rough idea from browser vendors when they plan to start abiding by html 5's recommendations?
even for existing elements (i.e. not counting all the fun new stuff)
it will be gradual
there aren't a lot of changes to existing elements though
(other than global stuff that applies to all elements)
i thought html5 was trying to get the browsers to act the same way in several places that they currently interpret the html spec differently
or are those mostly global things?
well, parsing is one big area where that is the case
but, for instance, there's nothing about the <b> element that would change in browsers
or
should change in some browser
what is the change?
othermaciej: has some dom interfaces that might need changing (like .complete)
er, members of the HTMLImageElement interface
Opera doesn't download the image, which I've found annoyingly inconsistent with other browsers
yeah, all other browsers will load images that are unrendered or not in the DOM
othermaciej, others: okay.  thanks :)
othermaciej: know if there's been any decision about <a>'s with display:block being allowed/allowing block elements inside or not?
Philip`: iirc we do because it saves bandwidth... which is important on mobiles
jacobolus: 'display' doesn't in any way change nesting rules
jacobolus: putting display: block on an <a> element is a consideration that is out of scope for the HTML spec
it's purely at the CSS level
and it is allowed
ah, okay
nesting block elements in <a> remains non-conforming I believe
othermaciej: I believe putting block elements in an <a> w/ display:block works just fine in all browsers, though :)
though in practice it is handled (not sure if the spec has full detail on how to handle it yet)
though it has been suggested that it should be allowed to nest blocks in lins
links
jacobolus: putting block elements in <a> without display:block also works
zcorpan_: hendry suggested the same reason
Philip`: what reason?
othermaciej: hmm, it caused some pretty nasty rendering issues in firefox though, when I tested it a few months ago (don't remember what version)
The saving-bandwidth-on-mobiles reason
Philip`: ah. yep
It's just annoying when I'm writing tests and using drawImage with s that shouldn't be visible, though maybe that's not an especially common use case :-)
(Now I tend to use visibility:hidden and stick them at the end of the document where nobody will notice them)
Philip`: new Image() creates an image that is not in the document but which generally loads and fires a load event
Philip`: perhaps that works in Opera even if doesn't
That does work in Opera, but I vaguely remember there being some reason why I didn't want to do that
but I have no idea what the actual reason was
Hmm, maybe it was just because I was lazy and preferred to write one line of HTML instead of two lines of JS
good morning
I don't understand what Sam Ruby is ranting about.  What's wrong with the way Firefox handles his test case? http://feedvalidator.org/testcases/atom/1.1/brief-noerror.xml
He "wanted to view the data in an XML parse tree" but Firefox thinks it's a feed
so what's wrong with that?  it is a feed.  He wouldn't expect an XHTML or SVG file delivered as application/xml to be rendered as a tree would he?
If you do 'data:application/xml,the stuff from that file' then it does display the tree instead of thinking it's a feed
(Not that that's a particularly relevant observation...)
wonders how any UA could ever distinguish between missing-alt and alt="", given that existing content presumably(?) mixes the two forms freely and future content will keep doing it wrong
Philip`: at least some UAs already treat the two cases differently
Hmm, Lynx is the only one I have that seems to care
(Links doesn't - it always ignores the image, unless it's in a link and then it says [IMG] instead)
Hixie: yt?
'lo
Greetings
Lynx supports a surprising number of HTML 3.0 features, which no other browser does that I'm aware of
(<tab>, <note>, <fn>, etc)
what does <note> do that's special?

"Lynx implements the HTML 3.0 NOTE element (Admonishment) as a labeled block, i.e., as if a new paragraph were indicated whether or not paragraphing markup is included in its content, with greater than normal left and right margins, and with the type of note indicated by an emphasized label based on the value of its CLASS or ROLE attribute. If no CLASS or ROLE attribute is included, the default label NOTE: will be used. Lynx recognizes the values cauti
... Lynx recognizes the values caution and warning, for which, respectively, the labels CAUTION: or WARNING: will be used."
http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/html3/notes.html
Hmm, it even lets you specify an image to accompany the note and an MD5 checksum of the image to ensure it hasn't been tampered with
Sounds like it'd be vaguely relevant to the various warning/note/etc boxes Wikipedia puts all over the place, like in the top of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5
that might be an interesting element to investigate.  Didn't we have class="note" predefined at one stage? Maybe that could be a non-controversial replacement
What would the value be, compared to writing plain text like "Warning: Leopards spotted"?
don't know.  That would be something that needed investigation. The best I can think of at this stage would be as a styling hook, but that's hardly good enough justification
Shouldn't you think of problems first and then find solutions, rather starting with the <note> solution and then thinking of problems for it to solve? :-p
*rather than
Lachy re: class="note".  We have defined that in hCard http://microformats.org/wiki/hcard per the NOTE property from RFC2426 section 3.6.2 NOTE Type Definition
Philip`, yes, that's right
back later, bye
It'd be nice if HTML5 <xmp> parsing was more like IE, and more like <pre>/<textarea> in all browsers, by ignoring a leading newline
Philip`: send it to the list? :) it would also affect getting innerHTML
what about <listing>? are there others?
I bet someone would just tell me that I shouldn't be writing new content with <xmp> :-(
but there's no way I'm going to bother with writing <s everywhere
that's not relevant to the proposal though
ie ignores the leading newline with listing and plaintext too

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C%21DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%3Cstyle%3Ebody%20*%20%7B%20border%3A%201px%20solid%20%7D%3C/style%3E%0D%0A%3Cbody%3E%0D%0A%0D%0A%3Cdiv%20style%3D%22white-space%3A%20pre%22%3E%0D%0A%0D%0Adiv%0D%0A%0D%0A%3C/div%3E%0D%0A%0D%0A%3Cpre%3E%0D%0A%0D%0Apre%0D%0A%0D%0A%3C/pre%3E%0D%0A%0D%0A%3Ctextarea%20rows%3D5%3E%0D%0A%0D%0Atextarea%0D%0A%0D%0A%3C/textarea%3E%0D%0A%0D%0A%3Cxmp%3E%0D%0A%0D%0Axmp%0D%0A%0D%0A%3
Urgh, too long
Anyway, IE seems to not render the leading newline with div either
nor include it in the innerHTML output
but it's probably not needed for <div>
Oh, how nice - IE's innerHTML changes depending on whether you've got CSS white-space:pre or not
why am i not surprised
hmm, where's the zombie dom viewer?
http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/misc/dom-viewer/
Useful for http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/misc/dom-viewer/?%3C%21DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%3Cplaintext%3Efoo in Opera
yeah
does w() work with the dead dom viewer?
No
we ignore the leading newline with <listing> but not <xmp> or <plaintext>
since I can't think of any way to inject the function into the page
ok
Everyone seems to do <listing> the same
(i.e. not the same as HTML5)
firefox crashes for me when i try <listing>x in the live dom viewer

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%3Cscript%3Ewindow.onload%3Dfunction(){w(document.body.firstChild.firstChild.data.length)}%3C/script%3E%3Cbody%3E%3Clisting%3E
then type an x
IE really is very very crazy
Non-deterministically so, as far as I can see...

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C%21DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%3Cstyle%3Ebody%20*%20%7B%20border%3A%201px%20solid%20%7D%3C/style%3E%0D%0A%3Cbody%20onload%3D%22with%28document.body%29%7Bfor%28var%20i%3D0%3Bi%3CchildNodes.length%3B++i%29w%28%27%3E%3E%3E%27+childNodes%5Bi%5D.firstChild.nodeValue+%27%3C%3C%3C%27%29%7D%22%3E%3Cdiv%20style%3D%22white-space%3A%20pre%22%3E%0D%0A%0D%0Adiv%20white-space%3Apre%0D%0A%0D%0A%3C/div%3E
If I add a character onto the end, then an extra newline appears in the top of the rendered div
but when I use my copy of the DOM viewer, the newline randomly appears and disappears when I add or remove characters on the end
(in IE7)
I don't get the <listing> crash in FF2
firefox 3
ok, so the leading newline is only needed for <listing>. not <xmp> or <plaintext>
will post to the list
(hopefully without too many errors)

I'd just be happy if html5lib stripped the newline from <xmp>, regardless of what browsers do, so I wouldn't have to write lines of code to manipulate the DOM and fix up the text while transforming it into <pre><code> :-)
(though maybe that's a selfish reason, and it's only about two lines of code anyway)
Argh
replies to himself
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C%21DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Cbody%20onload%3D%22w%28%27ok%27%29%7D%22%3E - why does Firefox accept that?
Oh, it's fixed in FF3
and <listing> crashes for me in FF3
Philip`: will Hixie find that message again when it doesn't contain "detailed review" in the subject...? :)

It's not part of a detailed review at all - it's just a random comment about something that I only noticed because I'm being silly and using <xmp> - so I wouldn't want to be misleading in the subject :-)
uses "detailed review" in his public-html messages that he wants the editors to find, even though they're random comments
<listing> isn't silly though as there's interop already
I've added it to the SpecReviews wiki page, since hopefully things there won't get too lost
that should work too, indeed
Perhaps I could also set up a blog anywhere on the internet and post it there, and I expect Hixie would find it through his magic finding-anything-anybody-says-about-HTML5-on-blogs powers
He probably uses (shock) google :)
Nah, I bet he's a closet Live Search user
How can you not like a search engine whose front page says "Get Pimped!"?
Philip`: has the live.com front page actually said that?
It said it when I looked at it just now
"Get Pimped! FREE emoticon packs for Messenger" linking to http://www.pimpmylive.co.uk/
ooh. there's a changing ad on reload
well, MTV still has enough impact to make the word "pimp" suitable for the front page of a corporate property
btw, does live.com have live search feeds for a term like Google and Technorati?
hah. live.com uses bitmaps for non-Latin-script language names.
can't Microsoft just install the full load of fonts and locale-specific algorithms with the default install and get rid of the IE language pack nag dialogs?
http://blogs.msdn.com/michkap/archive/2006/10/10/813347.aspx - sounds like in Vista they decided to just install everything
cool
and then people complain about bloat :-)
disk is cheap. configuration-specific quality assurance isn't
